# Problem 14 {.unnumbered} ::: {.callout-note icon=false} ## Problem

The following iterative sequence is defined for the set of positive integers:

  • $n \to n/2$ ($n$ is even)
  • $n \to 3n + 1$ ($n$ is odd)

Using the rule above and starting with $13$, we generate the following sequence: $13 \to 40 \to 20 \to 10 \to 5 \to 16 \to 8 \to 4 \to 2 \to 1.$

It can be seen that this sequence (starting at $13$ and finishing at $1$) contains $10$ terms. Although it has not been proved yet (Collatz Problem), it is thought that all starting numbers finish at $1$.

Which starting number, under one million, produces the longest chain?

NOTE: Once the chain starts the terms are allowed to go above one million.

::: ### Julia ::: {.cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} function collatz(n::Integer) seq = BigInt[] s = BigInt(n) while s > 1 push!(seq, s) if s % 2 == 0 s = div(s, 2) else s = 3*s + 1 end end push!(seq, 1) return seq end ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=2} ``` collatz (generic function with 1 method) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=2} ``` {.julia .cell-code} function p14() n, max_chain_length = 1, 1 for i âˆˆ 1:999_999 c = collatz(i) l = length(c) if l > max_chain_length n, max_chain_length = i, l end end return "The biggest chain starts in $n and has $max_chain_length" end; # p14() ``` ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=3} ``` {.julia .cell-code} # using BenchmarkTools; # @benchmark p14() ``` :::
